Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I could see the tears in my stepbrother’s eyes as we sat together on the bench outside the train station. He had just gotten the call—his mom, my stepmom, was in the hospital again, and this time it sounded serious. I wanted to be there for him, to listen, to comfort him, to show him that I was more than just a step-sibling—I was family. But my stomach rumbled, reminding me that I hadn’t eaten since morning. The only kosher vendor in this small town was about to close, and if I missed it, I’d have nothing to eat until tomorrow. My stepbrother, lost in his grief, didn’t notice the time. I felt torn—if I left now, even for a few minutes, would he feel abandoned? But if I stayed, I’d be breaking a promise to myself and my faith. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
